questions.text: Determine the cardiac output! Oxygen consumption: 2000mL/min, arterial oxygen concentration: 20mL/100mL, venous oxygen concentration: 10 mL/100mL (S)

metadata.matchReason: Fick principle: CO = VO2/(CaO2-CvO2) = 2000/(200-100) = 20 L/min - Topic 37: Cardiac output

questions.text: Renal blood flow is about 20% of the resting cardiac output. Which of the following statements is true concerning renal vascular resistance? (S)

options.text: renal vascular resistance does not contribute to total peripheral resistance
renal vascular resistance is about 20% of total peripheral resistance
renal vascular resistance is about 80% of total peripheral resistance
renal vascular resistance is about 500% of total peripheral resistance

metadata.matchReason: Renal blood flow and vascular resistance - Topic 45: Renal blood flow, glomerular filtration

questions.text: The Fahraeus-Lindquist effect: (S)

options.text: blood viscosity decreases with increasing shear rate
blood viscosity decreases in small tubes corresponding with vessel sizes in the microcirculation
blood viscosity decreases with decreasing hematocrit
blood viscosity decreases with increasing body temperature

metadata.matchReason: Fahraeus-Lindquist effect describes decreased apparent viscosity in vessels <300um - Topic 41: Microcirculation

questions.text: The venous pulse: (S)

options.text: is a result of pressure changes in the heart propagated to neighboring veins
is produced by rhythmic contractions of the smooth muscles of the veins that is the main force helping the cardiac filling

metadata.matchReason: Jugular venous pulse reflects right atrial pressure changes - Topic 40: Venous system

questions.text: Blood flow in the terminal vasculature of systemic circulation: (M)

options.text: the diameter of the capillaries is importantly modified by nervous stimulation
increases with increasing local CO2 concentration

metadata.matchReason: Local metabolic autoregulation (hypoxia, CO2) - Topic 41: Microcirculation

questions.text: Mediators which cause vasodilatation: (M)

metadata.matchReason: CGRP and VIP are vasodilators; TXA2, 5-HT, ET-1 are vasoconstrictors - Topic 41: Microcirculation

questions.text: Net capillary filtration increases, if: (M)

options.text: the activity of muscle pump increases

metadata.matchReason: Starling equation: increased Kf and decreased oncotic pressure increase filtration - Topic 39: Capillaries, transcapillary exchange

questions.text: The most effective factor enhancing venous return is (S)

options.text: negative hydrostatic pressure in the veins above the heart

metadata.matchReason: Skeletal muscle pump is the most powerful mechanism for venous return - Topic 40: Venous system

questions.text: Local hypoxia elicits vasoconstriction in the resistance vessels of (S)

metadata.matchReason: Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV) is unique to lungs - Topic 26: Pulmonary circulation, gas exchange

questions.text: The baroreceptors: (M)

options.text: when activated, they stimulate the bulbar cardioinhibitory area
are situated in the carotid and aortic bodies
are innervated with afferent fibers projecting to the nucleus of the solitary tract
are found exclusively in the high pressure-part of the circulatory system

metadata.matchReason: Baroreceptors are mechanoreceptors projecting to NTS - Topic 43: Short-term BP regulation

questions.text: The intrapleural pressure rises above the atmospheric pressure: (S)

options.text: it is always higher than the atmospheric pressure

metadata.matchReason: Valsalva maneuver increases intrathoracic pressure above atmospheric - Topic 25: Mechanics of breathing

questions.text: Which of the following cells belong to JGA? (M)

options.text: the podocytes of the Bowman capsule
the external epithelial cells of the Bowman capsule
smooth muscle cells of the efferent arteriole
(myoepithelial) granular cells of the afferent arteriole

metadata.matchReason: JGA: macula densa + juxtaglomerular cells of afferent arteriole - Topic 45: Renal blood flow, glomerular filtration

questions.text: The patient produces 1 ml urine each minute. The plasma osmotic concentration is 300 milliosmol/l, the urine osmotic concentrations is 900 milliosmol/L. Which of the following statements are true? (M)

options.text: the patient's free water clearance is 0 ml/min
the patient's free water clearance is 3 ml/min
the patient's free water clearance is -2 ml/min
the patient's osmotic clearance is 3 ml/min
the patient's osmotic clearance is 0.33 ml/min

metadata.matchReason: Cosm = (Uosm x V)/Posm = 3 ml/min; CH2O = V - Cosm = -2 ml/min - Topic 48: Renal concentration/dilution

questions.text: The correct definition of GFR is as follows (S)

options.text: the quantity of blood filtered through the glomerular capillaries each minute in all nephrons of both kidneys
the quantity of glomerular filtrate formed each minute in all nephrons of both kidneys
the quantity of blood filtered in a nephron in a minute
the fraction of the blood flow that becomes filtrate each min

metadata.matchReason: GFR is volume of plasma filtrate per unit time - Topic 45: Renal blood flow, glomerular filtration

questions.text: The effect of ADH is (S)

options.text: increase the permeability of the peritubular capillaries
increase the water permeability of the proximal tubules
increase the water permeability of the collecting tubules
increase the capillary permeability in the glomerulus

metadata.matchReason: ADH inserts AQP2 channels in collecting duct - Topic 48: Renal concentration/dilution

questions.text: What happens to K+ in the kidney? (S)

metadata.matchReason: K+ is filtered, reabsorbed in PCT/loop, secreted in CD - Topic 47: Tubular secretion

questions.text: The plasma glucose concentration when glucose first appears in the urine is (S)

metadata.matchReason: Renal glucose threshold ~10-11 mmol/L when SGLT2 saturates - Topic 46: Tubular reabsorption

options.text: determine the final pH of the urine
are supporting cells in between the principal cells
are important for the reabsorption of water
are important for the reabsorption of urea
